awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Flexible Printed OLED Displays
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is the creation of low-cost, flexible displays allowing smart objects to better communicate with their users. Researchers estimate that in 2017 there were 20 billion devices connected to the Internet that were not computers, estimated to grow to 125 billion by 2025. These Internet of Things devices are already used in many applications for transportation, health and wellness, factory production, public safety, retail, agriculture, homes, and offices. These devices can enable better resource allocation, predictive maintenance, operations management, worker training, task automation, energy management, and safety; they will require displays that are thin, low power, flexible or curved, and easy to read. A near-term need is autonomous transportation, which will need a method of visual communication between vehicle and rider.  This project will develop organic light emitting diode (OLED) displays; just this initial transportation application will help improve mobility for the elderly and disabled, traffic safety, and related needs.  In the longer term, this project will enable manufacturing of improved displays with reduced processing waste.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will develop roll-to-roll printed passive matrix (OLED) displays. These displays are built upon a patterned transparent conductive anode that defines the pixels. To date, the only method used in industry to create this anode is photolithography, a slow and expensive process. The high-resolution printable anode developed here replaces both the incumbent material and the lithographic process, laying the foundation for fully roll-to-roll printed displays.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Because OLED is inherently a thin-film display and lighting technology, it has been an industry-wide vision for these panels to be plastic-based and flexible. The use of a flexible substrate should represent the opportunity to rethink how an OLED is produced. But to date, there are no display panels on the market that are manufactured any differently than those based on glass.

Flexography is a high-throughput printing process used for plastic and paper goods. It is an established industry with the ability to make low-cost products at high volume. OLEDs produced flexographically could compete in the market with LCDs and LED assemblies, while retaining the high quality OLED is known for. 

Sinovia has successfully used production-scale roll-to-roll flexographic printing equipment to manufacture bottom-emitting OLEDs, roll-to-roll, from start to finish, including encapsulation. We demonstrated high-resolution patterning of our proprietary transparent conductive film, as well as smooth, pinhole-free printing of four organic active layers, at targeted thicknesses between 20 and 200 nm. To do this, the team iterated through ink formulations and process conditions, including printing plate design, web speeds, post-processing conditions, and other control settings. The performance of these OLEDs is on par with benchtop-processed controls with respect to brightness, efficiency, uniformity, and lifetime. 


Last Modified: 01/24/2025
Modified by: Whitney Gaynor

Image
  • Sinovia's roll-to-roll OLEDs, printed on industrial flexographic equipment.

    Roll-to-roll printed OLEDs
